member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Devices.Device
member.summary: Forwards messages received by a front-end socket to a back-end socket, from which they are then sent.
member.remarks: The base implementation of is not threadsafe. Do not construct a device with sockets that were created in separate threads or separate contexts.

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Devices.ForwarderDevice
member.summary: Collects messages from a set of publishers and forwards these to a set of subscribers.
member.remarks: Generally used to bridge networks. E.g. read on TCP unicast and forward on multicast. This device is part of the publish-subscribe pattern. The frontend speaks to publishers and the backend speaks to subscribers.

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Devices.QueueDevice
member.summary: A shared queue that collects requests from a set of clients and distributes these fairly among a set of services.
member.remarks: Requests are fair-queued from frontend connections and load-balanced between backend connections. Replies automatically return to the client that made the original request. This device is part of the request-reply pattern. The frontend speaks to clients and the backend speaks to services.

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Devices.StreamerDevice
member.summary: Collects tasks from a set of pushers and forwards these to a set of pullers.
member.remarks: Generally used to bridge networks. Messages are fair-queued from pushers and load-balanced to pullers. This device is part of the pipeline pattern. The frontend speaks to pushers and the backend speaks to pullers.

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.ZmqSocket.Close
member.summary: Destroy the current socket.
member.remarks: Any outstanding messages physically received from the network but not yet received by the application with Receive shall be discarded. The behaviour for discarding messages sent by the application with Send but not yet physically transferred to the network depends on the value of the socket option.
member.exception: The underlying socket object is not valid.

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.ZmqSocket.Receive(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Receive a single message-part from a remote socket in blocking mode (high performance).
member.remarks: Warning: This overload will only receive as much data as can fit in the supplied Up to . Any message data beyond the maximum length will be discarded. It is intended to be used when the maximum messaging performance is required; it will not allocate a new buffer (or copy received data) if the received message exceeds the current buffer size. If the maximum message size is not known in advance, use the overload.
member.param: A array that will store the received data.
member.returns: The number of bytes contained in the resulting message.
member.exception: is null.
An error occurred receiving data from a remote endpoint.
The has been closed.
The current socket type does not support Receive operations.

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Interop.UnmanagedLibrary
member.summary: Utility class to wrap an unmanaged shared lib and be responsible for freeing it.
member.remarks: This is a managed wrapper over the native LoadLibrary, GetProcAddress, and FreeLibrary calls on Windows and dlopen, dlsym, and dlclose on Posix environments.

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.Interop.UnmanagedLibrary.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Loads a dll and takes responible for freeing it.
member.remarks: Throws exceptions on failure. Most common failure would be file-not-found, that the file is not a loadable image.
member.param: full path name of dll to load
member.exception: if fileName can't be found

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.Interop.UnmanagedLibrary.GetUnmanagedFunction``1(System.String)
member.summary: Dynamically look up a function in the dll via kernel32!GetProcAddress or libdl!dlsym.
member.param: Raw name of the function in the export table.
member.returns: A delegate to the unmanaged function.
member.exception: Thrown if the given function name is not found in the library.
member.remarks: GetProcAddress results are valid as long as the dll is not yet unloaded. This is very very dangerous to use since you need to ensure that the dll is not unloaded until after you're done with any objects implemented by the dll. For example, if you get a delegate that then gets an IUnknown implemented by this dll, you can not dispose this library until that IUnknown is collected. Else, you may free the library and then the CLR may call release on that IUnknown and it will crash.

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Monitoring.ZmqMonitor
member.summary: A socket monitoring object.
member.remarks: CAUTION: is intended for monitoring infrastructure / operations concerns only - NOT BUSINESS LOGIC. An event is a representation of something that happened - you cannot change the past, but only react to them. The implementation is also only concerned with a single session. No state of peers, other sessions etc. are tracked - this will only pollute internals and is the responsibility of application authors to either implement or correlate in another datastore. Monitor events are exceptional conditions and are thus not directly in the messaging critical path. However, still be careful with what you're doing in the event handlers as excess time spent in the handler will block the socket's application thread.

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.Monitoring.ZmqMonitor.Unregister

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.Poller
member.summary: Multiplexes input/output events in a level-triggered fashion over a set of sockets.

remarks.para: Sockets will be polled according to their capabilities. For example, sockets that are receive-only (e.g., PULL and SUB sockets) will only poll for Input events. Sockets that can both send and receive (e.g., REP, REQ, etc.) will poll for both Input and Output events.
To actually send or receive data, the socket's and/or event handlers must be attached to. If attached, these will be invoked when data is ready to be received or sent.

member.name: T:ZeroMQ.SocketType
member.summary: Specifies possible socket types defined by ZMQ messaging patterns.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.PAIR
member.summary: Can only be connected to a single peer at any one time. Part of the Exclusive Pair pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.PUB
member.summary: Used by a publisher to distribute messages in a fan out fashion to all connected peers. Part of the Publish-Subscribe pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.SUB
member.summary: Used by a subscriber to subscribe to data distributed by a publisher. Part of the Publish-Subscribe pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.REQ
member.summary: Used by a client to send requests to and receive replies from a service. Part of the Request-Reply pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.REP
member.summary: Used by a service to receive requests from and send replies to a client. Part of the Request-Reply pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.DEALER
member.summary: Used for extending request/reply sockets. Each message sent is round-robined among all connected peers, and each message received is fair-queued from all connected peers.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.ROUTER
member.summary: Used for extending request/reply sockets. Messages received are fair-queued from among all connected peers.
member.remarks: When receiving messages a socket shall prepend a message part containing the identity of the originating peer to the message before passing it to the application. When sending messages a ZMQ_ROUTER socket shall remove the first part of the message and use it to determine the identity of the peer the message shall be routed to. If the peer does not exist anymore the message shall be silently discarded.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.PULL
member.summary: Used by a pipeline node to receive messages from upstream pipeline nodes. Part of the Pipeline pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.PUSH
member.summary: Used by a pipeline node to send messages to downstream pipeline nodes. Part of the Pipeline pattern.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.XPUB
member.summary: Same as except subscriptions can be received from peers as incoming messages. Part of the Publish-Subscribe pattern.
member.remarks: Subscription message is a byte '1' (for subscriptions) or byte '0' (for unsubscriptions) followed by the subscription body.

member.name: F:ZeroMQ.SocketType.XSUB
member.summary: Same as except subscription messages can be sent to the publisher. Part of the Publish-Subscribe pattern.
member.remarks: Subscription message is a byte '1' (for subscriptions) or byte '0' (for unsubscriptions) followed by the subscription body.

member.remarks: The object is a container for all sockets in a single process, and acts as the transport for inproc sockets. is thread safe. A must not be terminated until all spawned sockets have been successfully closed.

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.ZmqContext.Terminate
member.summary: Terminate the ZeroMQ context.
member.remarks:
Context termination is performed in the following steps:
Any blocking operations currently in progress on sockets open within context shall return immediately with an error code of ETERM. With the exception of , any further operations on sockets open within the context shall fail with a .
After interrupting all blocking calls, shall block until the following conditions are met:
All sockets open within the context have been closed with .
For each socket within the context, all messages sent by the application have either been physically transferred to a network peer, or the socket's linger period set with the socket option has expired.
member.exception: The has already been disposed.
An error occurred creating the socket.

member.name: M:ZeroMQ.ZmqContext.CreateMonitor
member.summary: Create a socket monitoring object.
member.remarks: Only a single instance per context is allowed. Use to unregister the monitoring object or dispose it.
member.returns: A instance with the monitoring object for the current context.
member.exception: An error occurred while creating the monitor object.
The has already been created for the current context.
